definitions.definition: a period of 24 hours, especially from twelve o'clock one night to twelve o'clock the next night:
used to refer to the period in 24 hours when it is naturally light:
the time that you usually spend at work or at school:
a day when you do not have to work or do something that you normally do:
examples: I won't be in on Thursday - it's my day off.
Didn't I see you in the post office the other day?

definitions.definition: used to talk about the present time, in comparison with the past:
examples: Vegetarianism is very popular these days.
In those days people used to write a lot more letters.

definitions.definition: very soon, especially within the next few days:
examples: The baby's due any day now.
The same problems keep coming up day after day.
You can hear the traffic from your room day and night.

definitions.definition: every day, or more and more as each day passes:
examples: Day by day he became weaker.

definitions.definition: If something changes (from) day to day, it changes often:
examples: The symptoms of the disease change from day to day.
I never know what I’ll be doing from one day to the next.
How did people communicate in the days before email?

definitions.definition: up to and including the present moment:
examples: To this day nobody knows what happened to him.
